However, you forget to mention the third reason which further miniaturization of such ICs may face. every transistor is fabricated over the Si wafer which itself is a electrical conductor through which current/electrons are traveling. These results in local HOT-SPOT of nanometer size. the heat flux density over these Hot-spot is expected to go beyond 1000W/cm^2 in 2020 which needs to be dissipate for the successful operation of ICs otherwise these electronic components will fail.

Yeah, same as everything else in the universe really. We have more resources to work with, so we build better stuff. There'd not a whole lot of reason for any software designer to be smaller at any significant compromise of features - because they know they'll have twice as many resources next year anyway.

Foust2014 It's equitable but is it sustainable? And would average computer user be more satisfied with computer that offers lots of features which will never be used or with super fast software that does exactly what user needs? I'm prone to thinking that it's capitalistic view of the world where it is more important to spend and earn that anything else.

If you want an incredibly fast computer that does "everything the user needs", by which definition of "user needs" are you choosing to use? What do you need?   Feature bloat is a thing, it's always going to be a thing. It's always been a thing. There is nothing to be gained from standing at the sidelines of an industry whose subtleties elude you, and pointing out half a phenomenon everyone is aware of.   The "other half" of the issue, if you were wondering. Essentially everything you use was at one point (in the very recent past mind you) something people would call useless funny-named nonsense. I'm not even talking about computing here, I'm talking about literally every advancement since silly childish men wasted their time sharpening stones instead of gathering more berries.

Actually,  humans DO still manually lay out millions of transistors on modern IC's!    VLSI and place-and-route logic synthesis has it's place but human-driven physical design for the most critical components is still a huge part of the chip design process.  Photomask design has been my career for over 15 years  :)
PDP-8 was using integrated circuits. But yeah, the backplanes were horrid.

To add on the limit of Moore's Law. At some point in the future making the transistors smaller cannot be achieved since then the size of a transistor will be in the order of a few atom. However, Moore's Law does not directly have anything to do with the size of a transistor, but with the number of transistors per IC. This can also be achieved by other methods like 3D-stacking of transistors. For those curious, I would advise to google a bit, there is plenty of information on the topic available.

That's actually the power of abstraction. You can turn low-level tech into high-tech and make it look like magic (I mean mathematics). For example, the first levels were literally turning on and off a switch.

Yeah, it's another application of a technology that was around at the time.  The same process was used to make the first PCBs:  Take a fiberglass board, coat both sides with copper.  Use photoresist and etching to remove unwanted copper, and you're left with copper "traces" - a.k.a. wires - on both sides of the board.  Then drill the holes through, and you've got a PCB.

Moore's law is still valid, in the form of multi cores. first, there are two. then four. then eight. I believe we have 18 now. still keep going on.
Unfortunately multicores have diminishing returns because of the fact that dependencies within code prevent most programs from making use of that many cores.

+simpletongeek: It is true that multiple cores help.  But also remember that for there to be more cores without increasing the size means that each core needs to be smaller, hence the transistors within them need to be smaller, so in the end, while more cores let more processes go on at the same time, they cannot get over the fact of a minimum transistor size.

Moore's law is that the density of transistors on a 2D plane doubles every 2 years, not that the number of transistors per device doubles. Having more cores doesn't help us do things more quickly; it helps us do more things at once.

Diamond semiconductors that could withstand higher clock speeds, quantum mechanics normalized transistor architecture, single atomic transistors, whatever the successor to lithography would be.  There are any number of ways moores law could be extended. The current slump doesn't disprove the overall trend.

+TheSmileyFacedPizza But but but! By having more cores, it's possible to split a problem into several sub-problems which can then be worked on simultaneously, thus speeding up the overall problem-solving process. Of course the operating system will need more complexity to be able to determine which tasks (sub-problems)) can feasibly be 'split off' into separate tasks, but with the powerful CPUs modern computers employ, it should, generally speaking, result in a measurable speed-up.

There are no problems that can be split up; there are multiple problems that we solve one at a time. Adding cores simply allows us to solve more of those problems at once. There will always be limits to how much we can multithread something. For example, if I wanted to find the average between two numbers, you must first add the numbers then divide by two or divide by two then add the numbers, although the second one is far less efficient. You can't have one thread adding the numbers and another thread dividing the numbers because the result of one is the input of the other. That's why so many applications take up a single thread. Tons of calculations done by computers are sequential, so to speed them up, we need faster cores, not more cores. More cores are nice, though, depending on the application. Faster cores are nice, always.  edit: It's up to the programmer and the compiler to parallelize. Having the OS do it would be way less efficient. It's simple compared to other things programmers must do and think about. If you ask me, I think knowing how to optimally parallelize whenever possible is part of being a not mediocre programmer.

Rationalific Moore's law deals with performance, instead of manufacturing concerns. If you consider that a room sized computer can now be had on a chip, then logically, current room sized petaflops supercomputer with its numerous CPUs will be shrunk to laptop size in the future. That's assuming density stays the same.   If nothing else, storage costs will be cheaper. Cost is another effect of Moore's law.

TheSmileyFacedPizza Many problems can be easily solved in parallel. Databases, Raytracing, Particle simulation, AI problem solving, etc. OS can automatically do some of it. Vector processing can be easily done that way. Pipelining calculations is already done automatically. Anything multi-threaded is certainly doable. Beowulf project does that. No problem at all.

I never said there weren't tons of multithreaded applications. I'm just saying that multithreading is only part of the problem, one that can always be solved by adding more cores through supercomputing. However, a supercomputer will still load up programs more slowly and have hard times doing sequential workloads because supercomputers are made to be slow. If we simply focus on single-threaded speed, those improvements will show everywhere, from single-threaded applications to supercomputing, and cores can always just be stacked on. Especially nowadays with AMD's Infinity Fabric and potentially Intel's new mesh, adding more cores is easy. Making actual improvements is not.
